results.title: Ninety degrees south
results.brief_description: This famous film is the official record of Captain Scott’s last Expedition to the Antarctic in 1912. The film tells of the hazardous journey to the South and includes the last photographs of Scott, Evans, Wilson, and Oates, who were lost. In photographing this film, Herbert Ponting, “Camera Artist” to the Expedition, faced great hardships and narrowly escaped death on a number of occasions. 1934 soundtrack added to original silent documentary of 1912.

results.title: Nightmail
results.creator_credit: GPO Film Unit, John Grierson, Basil Wright and Harry Watt
results.brief_description: Classic British documentary recounting the journey of the ‘Postal Special’ train from London to Glasgow. Carrying no passengers, the postal staff sort mail on board and receive and despatch mailbags ‘en route’. The non professional cast performed scripted scenes, giving a human dimension to the mechanics of mail delivery. Along with a dry factual voice-over, the soundtrack offered music by composer Benjamin Britten and verse by W.H. Auden.

results.title: A Night to remember [study extract]
results.creator_credit: William MacQuitty, Rank Organisation Film Productions and Roy Baker
results.brief_description: An extract from “A Night to remember”, directed by Roy Baker and based on the book by Walter Lord. Shows the Captain giving the order to abandon ship and the subsequent reactions of the passengers and the crew. Cast includes Kenneth More, Laurence Naissmith, Thomas Andrews, Michael Goodliffe.

results.title: Nice time
results.creator_credit: BFI, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner
results.brief_description: A notable experimental documentary featuring the sights and sounds of Piccadilly Circus on a Saturday night. Music by Chas McDevitt Skiffle Group. Cinematography and sound by John Fletcher.

results.title: The New alchemists
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, ONF | NFB and Dorothy Todd Henaut
results.brief_description: On a small farm, a group of people explore the possibilities for more self-sustaining communities involving interrelated food-producing systems and small scale technology. From the “Challenge for change” series”.

results.title: The Nazis strike
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra and United States. War Dept.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Why we fight”.
This unnerving film examines the growth of Hitler’s Nazi Party, which became mankind’s single most destructive force. Includes Hitler’s closest aides and key figures, the denouncing of all religious belief as weak and petty, and the atrocities which promised German world domination. Concludes with the invasions of Austria, Czechoslovakia and Poland. This film was originally intended for the orientation of members of the armed forces during the war. Narrated by Walter Huston and Captain Anthony Veiller. Editing, Major William Hornbeck. Music, Dimitri Tiomkin.

results.title: The Navigator
results.brief_description: Buster “Keaton moves in the mechanised world of today like the inhabitant of another planet. He gazes with frozen bewilderment at a nightmare reality. Inventions and contrivances like deck chairs and railroad engines seem insuperably animate to him, in the same measure that human beings become impersonal.” Arthur Mayer. In “The Navigator”, which grossed more than any other Keaton film, it was a huge luxury liner. There is the famous sequence in which Keaton gloomily sets about cooking his breakfast, in a ship’s galley equipped to feed five hundred people. Painfully, he times an egg as it boils in a huge cauldron. The plot of “The Navigator” inverts the problem of Robinson Crusoe. Crusoe had to create the rudiments of civilisation on a desert island. Keaton, playing a dim-witted millionaire, finds himself and his girl marooned in an over-technical environment. He has to create the basis for crude existence. Considered by many Keaton buffs to be the funniest film he ever made.

results.title: Muscle beach
results.creator_credit: Strick Film Company, J Strick and I Lerner
results.brief_description: A humorous and poetic impression of the pursuit of physical culture on the San Monica Beach, California. The languor’s of a summer afternoon are contrasted satirically with the fervours of the body builders and devotees of physical exercise.

results.title: A Moment in love
results.brief_description: A ballet choreographed by Anna Sokolow and designed for camera by Shirley Clarke, featuring movements and images physically impossible to perform on stage. Depicts the passion between two lovers who meet in the clouds and move through a world of fantasy. The dancers are Carmela Gutierrez and Paul Sanasardo. Music, Norman Lloyd. Cinematography, Bert and Shirley Clarke. A film without commentary.

results.title: Moliere
results.creator_credit: Elvire Chessin, Norbert Tildian and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: The world and environment of Moliere portrayed in 17th century drawings and paintings. His satirical comedies “Tartuffe”, “Les Ecole des Femmes”, “L’Avarre” and “Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme” are discussed. Several scenes from the plays, spoken in French, are incorporated. The actors are from La Comedie Francaise. Main commentary in English.
